Tim

Pro-gunners are fond of saying things like "we don't need more gun-control laws, we need tougher punishments and longer prison sentences." Yet America has capital punishment and the world's highest incarceration rate and still we have very high rates of gun violence compared to other developed nations like Australia and the UK.
 
 "More than 5.6 million Americans are in prison or have served time there, according to a new report by the Justice Department released Sunday. That's 1 in 37 adults living in the United States, the highest incarceration level in the world."
 http://www.worldrevolution.org/article/984 
 
 So I certainly have doubts about the plan of pro-gunners to reduce gun violence.

Yes I do have to conced the point to our anti-gunner VOR, yes that those countires DO NOT large stocks of privately owned firearms like the USA. No they don't, the government instead gives them away. The government ownes the guns, but the citizens have them in thier closets.
 
 Would you be afraid of a teenager with a full auto machine gun ridding a public bus with you? Apparently the Iserali have no problem with it. When teenagers in the Army go home on weekends, they are still on active duy for the weekend, thus they take thier primary weapon with them. Since most of them do not have cars, they hitch hike or ride the bus. Would you have a problem with your the people on your street, when each one of them has a full auto machinegun in the closet? Apparently not the Swiss. With a very small standing army, every male of age who is capable is in the army. Thus every man of age has a bicycle, food, shelter, gas mask, uniform, ammo, and machinegun in the closet.
 
 The Swiss and the Isreali show that a society have be armed to the teeth and not use guns to kill each other. The USA has a violence problem, not a gun problem.

Are you sure about that? "THE United States is the most heavily-armed nation on Earth, 255E401,00.html[/url] 
 
 ?

 
 Thank you for the info. I stand corrected. Do you know if that is counting civilian arms or military arms?
 
 My plan?
 
 1) Instant background checks for gun purchases.
 2) No waiting period.
 3) Concealed carry for upstanding and law abiding citizens.
 4) No children allowed into movies with violent content without parental concent.
 5) Increased budget for Public Television and PBS programming.
 5) Youth recreation, sports, and afterschool activites with increased budgets.
 6) Increaced budgets for grade school education.
 7) Bigger prisons for violent offenders
 8) Education and training for non-violent offenders in prison.
 9) Enforcement of CURRENT GUN LAWS and increased budgets for law enforcement.
 10) But NOT increased budgets for law enforcement and gun control in the same bill before Congress. (Brady idea).
 11) Free drugs for drug abusers and increased budgets for treatment of drug abusers. (Drug abusers choice? Get high until you OD or get sober but not both.)
 12) Televised executions.
 13) Teaching my nieces and newphews to respect and honor God and elders. To stay in school and praise them for good citizenship and moral behavior.
 14) I am sure I missed a few, but anything that will reduce social ills and injustice.
 
 All of which will reduce conditions within society that are conductive to violence. Most important they are all Constitutional and do not infringe on civil rights. A gun does not teach a 16 year old to kill or teach them that killing is acceptable behavior. Nor does a gun make a peson violent. From my own stock piles of guns I should be the most violent person on my street if that were true.
 
 This country has a problem with violence, not guns. Look at all the trash that comes out of Hollywood. This country worships violence and admires men who use violence. It does not admire enginners, scientist, teachers, social workers, and clegy they way it should. Can you name the characters in T3? Can you name the Nobel Prize winner in Physics?
 
 What is your plan to reduce gun violence and not violate civil rights?
voiceofreason

This sounds like a common sense plan to reduce gun crime. Think about it:
 
 "Although I would personally like to see as many civilian-owned guns eliminated from mainstream society as possible, I realize that this is not a politically realistic goal. Thus, I present my own plans for gun control that I would consider a valid compromise. Perhaps policy discussions can start from these.
 
 1. A national system for registering guns and ammunition. Part of the reason New York City has stiff gun laws and high gun death rates is that anybody can go from New York to a state with less restrictive laws, get a friend who lives in the state to buy the guns for them, and take those guns back to NYC. (Yes, I am aware this is illegal, but it happens.) First, a national system would prevent this by scaring those "friends" into not buying the guns legally and selling them illegally, for if the guns are used in an illegal crime, that person can be held accountable. Second, a national system would be more helpful in tracking crimes after they have happened, to bring the perpetrators to justice. 
 
 2. Instant background checks on people attempting to buy guns or ammunition. Brady is still patchwork, and does indeed have its flaws in tracking felons. Felons and ex-cons should not have access to weapons, and many misdemeanors and juvenile crimes should also count against a person's record. 
 
 3. Stiffer sentences for gun crimes. This has been the position of the NRA for quite some time, and it is certainly one with which I agree. 
 
 4. Gun education. Many guns are involved in accidents that could easily have been prevented by a little care or forethought. Perhaps gun purchasers should be required to take lessons in gun safety, at the purchaser's expense. Again, the NRA has long been a proponent of gun education.
 
 5. General education. Study after study has concluded that there is a direct correlation between lack of education and violent crime. Every dollar spent on education now will prevent countless dollars worth of crime damage in the future. Think of all the private and public funds used to pay for gun violence -- hospital bills, funerals, insurance bills, the actual cost of buying firearms. Now invest that money in education, and watch the crime rate drop.
 
 6. Hand grip ID tagging. This is technologically probably still in the future, but it would be a good goal to work for. The theory is, each gun is "registered" to one's person palm prints (the legal purchaser of the gun), and only that person can fire that gun. If another person tries, the gun simply will not fire. Thus, stolen guns become useless, and cannot be used to harm anybody in the course of a crime."
 http://www.asahi-net.or.jp/~zj5j-gttl/guns.htm
kelvin90701

 6. Hand grip ID tagging. This is technologically probably still in the future, but it would be a good goal to work for. The theory is, each gun is "registered" to one's person palm prints (the legal purchaser of the gun), and only that person can fire that gun. If another person tries, the gun simply will not fire.  Here's why: Let's assume I buy a gun with this technology for home defense. Wonderful. Oh yeah, but for part of the year I work nights, so that means I need yet another gun for my girlfriend. Okay, so another gun isn't out of the question.
 
 But let's assume I'm at work one night, and my girlfriend, lying in bed, with our 18 month old daughter a few feet away suddenly hears someone in the house. She get's up, goes to the little hiding place and gets a gun. The perp swings open the bedroom door, she says "get out or I'll shoot" the perp moves closer, she pulls the trigger....but uh oh...she's got MY gun...and it won't fire........ 
 
 My point is, that this technology would work for stolen guns but there could be some serious drawbacks to it.

I've been thinking about a gun/ID idea for some time. most likely in the not-too-distant future they gonna start implanting microchips in people's hands. it will work as like e-z pass, ID, atm card, car keys and anything else you want it to be (including GPS, and probably monitoring your vital signs). eventually all buying and selling can be done via this chip, and every gun will be equiped with sensors that read the chip. therefore every gun held will be traceable to the person, time and location. gun violence will be so much easier to control
 
 and about the girlfriend/gun problem, just put your gun on a joint account. besides, the burglar wont be able to use his gun either, and he would be tracked down in no time if he held a gun he wasnt authorised to use, and in a house he wasnt authorized to be in

lol...
 
 if your familiar with "smart" cards or magnetic stripes, and now thermal dye ID cards, you'll realise that batteries are not required for any of them to work.
 
 I never said anybody would inject anything in you anytime soon, but I could pretty much assure you that you would accept the device if it was the only way to buy and sell. you have a credit card dont you? without it you cant buy stuff on the net or reserve a hotel room...
 
 Imagine a world where cash is totally non-existent. your savings balance is linked to your ID chip, as well as your social security, academic qualifications, basically everything about you is stored in a massive global database, linked to your unique encoded personal number embedded in the chip. thats all the chip has, a very long encrypted number. but it uniquely identifies you.
 
 now think of everything else in the world modified to accomodate this chip. you jump in a taxi, get out at the restaurant, eat a meal, go to work, or maybe work at home/on the road, go through your entire day without needing a wallet, keys, badges, or anything like that
 
 you could never get robbed, never get car-jacked, never get lost. in fact, the minute you are in a situation where you adrenaline gets flowing and your heart-rate rises due to alarm, your database account is flagged. emergency units would locate people in trouble in no time. criminals would be so much easier to trace, if any exist. 
 
 of course this is much bigger than gun control, and it is futuristic in terms of getting it globally accepted, but believe me, the technology for all this already exists.
 
 sure you'll have people who will try to beat the system, and of course crimes will still be committed. but getting away with crimes will be near completely eliminated
 
 think about it...

think about this: you use a credit card? checks? bank account? get paid through direct deposit? believe it or not, your spending habits and monetary transactions are being monitored more closely than you know...
 
 and the thing is, you do know. in fact, you're glad they monitor it, because credit reporting is based on your use of credit cards, payment of bills, salary deposits and spending tendencies. and you do want good credit, along with the hundreds of millions of other credit consumers that want good credit
 
 when the idea of credit card use to replace cash was introduced, there was just as big an opposition, and on the same grounds of invasion of privacy and 2nd Ammendment violation.
 
 nowadays, with the exception of things money cant buy, for everything else there's Master Card, and Visa everywhere you want to be, not to mention you cant leave home without your American Express. 
 
 think about E-Z Pass, the quick alternative to getting pass toll booths all over the country. of course your transit is being monitored, but people will sacrifice their 2nd Ammendment privilleges for convenience
 
 to me this is selling-out, but nobody is going to go back to the days of farming, hunting and gathering. 
 
 now look at the scenario I described. it definitely isnt a utopia of people living happily, but it certainly seems to be the direction that technological trends are heading. and it just might not meet as much opposition as you think...

". Part of the reason New York City has stiff gun laws and high gun death rates is that anybody can go from New York to a state with less restrictive laws, get a friend who lives in the state to buy the guns for them, and take those guns back to NYC"
 
 And those cities in states with the non restrictive gun laws have a lower crime rates then NYC....imagine that.
 
 
 "First, a national system would prevent this by scaring those "friends" into not buying the guns legally and selling them illegally"
 
 The value of imported illegal firearms would go up, and so would illegal sales. The number of illegally owned firearms in the nation would not drop, and neither would the violent crime rate.
 
 
 ". Second, a national system would be more helpful in tracking crimes after they have happened, to bring the perpetrators to justice. "
 
 You mean like the Canadian system? I don't recall it being successfully used yet.
 
 
 "Hand grip ID tagging. This is technologically probably still in the future, but it would be a good goal to work for. The theory is, each gun is "registered" to one's person palm prints (the legal purchaser of the gun), and only that person can fire that gun. "
 
 So if a cop loses their gun in a fight, and tries to pick up a buddies, they can't shoot it. So if a home is invaded, and the legal owner of a firearm is incapacitated, then no one else can defend themselves with the gun. 
 And do you believe that a skitchy electronic system could not be disabled? Do you believe that a reliable system that can make instant IDs
 in adverse conditions is possible? Do you not think that home-manufactured firearms without the system would crop up on the black market? Or that foreign imports, exempt from the laws, could become popular? An ID system would cause far more havoc than not. As for the problem of kids shooting themselves-which this idea may prevent the occasional case of-it can be solved through education, an ideal that you support.
